qas.question: What simple word does the term szlachta translate too?
What were the non noble land owners referred too as?
Why were the non nobles and nobles referred as the same term?

context: Today the word szlachta in the Polish language simply translates to "<a0_0>nobility<a0_0/>". In its broadest meaning, it can also denote some non-hereditary honorary knighthoods granted today by some European monarchs. Occasionally, 19th-century non-noble landowners were referred to as <a1_0>szlachta<a1_0/> <a2_0>by courtesy or error<a2_0/>, when they owned manorial estates though they were not noble by birth. In the narrow sense, szlachta denotes the <a3_0>old-Commonwealth nobility<a3_0/>.
